title: Missing trie node after 1 month of geth fully sync
body:
Hello, 

We're running full geth service and after ~ 1 - 2 months we're receiving this error inside geth (missing trie node) and resync from scratch is needed. This time we received the following error - this is pretty annoying since after some time geth is returning such error and we can't send transfers out or read blocks data because geth won't sync properly.

`exception: getDeleteStateObject (aa5952230aefc4c92a580c347a335bf7d4bb009d) error: missing trie node b639e8f6d3ec9d5a6d2b37d148f1e0d33b7a45e2e943b96e44d002c20bebc17d (path 0605) [] []`

#### System information

Geth version: 0.1.9.23
OS & Version: Debian 10
did the node run through or where there unclean shutdowns (e.g. due to reboots or crashes)?

@ligi We updated geth server at that time, but as you can see from geth logs, geth service was stopped. 
Here are full logs from that time

Thanks for the report. We are working on some tooling to repair the state, when situations like these arise. It's by no means a trivial task, however, and the tooling we have is not yet production ready. 

If you want to make an attempt at repairing it, however, you could try this PR: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/21650 . After building geth, you would run `./build/bin/geth repairtrie`. That will 'clean out' some corruptions, and put the node into a state where, next time you restart it, it will fast-sync to head, but based upon the existing database, so the healing should go much quicker than a regular fast-sync. 

There's no guarantee it will work, but it's definitely faster than a sync from scratch. If you are rnining an archive node, the end result might be that the state is missing for some blocks, but you would still retain most of all states.

Also, do you have any more context (log lines) around the `exception: getDeleteStateObject (aa5952230aefc4c92a580c347a335bf7d4bb009d) error: missing trie node b639e8f6d3ec9d5a6d2b37d148f1e0d33b7a45e2e943b96e44d002c20bebc17d (path 0605) ` error?

@holiman  

```

WARN [11-18|01:21:58.906] Served eth_getBalance                    conn=127.0.0.1:48400 reqid=50 t="188.187µs"  err="getDeleteStateObject (696334d05d8c57b94a8f0a7deddff4cdf90950cb) error: missing trie node 76039d8a7232257a741cb7f310d551ec5a7e0136e32526a2a058b3cc1c855307 (path 0402)"

The DB seems to be corrupted. It would need repair as @holiman suggested.
Is this an archive node you are running?

@ligi No, this is new geth server setup ~ 1 month ago. 
Geth is setup in **-syncmode=full** . We got this issue after some time also in other servers where we're running geth in same mode.
Do you have the `--gcmode "archive"` flag in your startup command? Lacking that might be the cause of the issue.
@wbt  No we don't have such flag in our startup command

Add that in before your next resync, and keep in there for your subsequent startups.  Otherwise it probably will start to prune older data after a month or two to save on disk space, and you'll get the missing trie node error.  Speaking from experience, I can agree that's frustrating and hard to debug, but hopefully that flag will help solve it!

(Note: also make sure you have plenty of disk space...things can silently fail when the disk fills, in a way that can also be puzzling and nontrivial to debug.)

@wbt This is not the case.
We have plenty of space on our servers and when issue with "missing trie node" happened we just keep keystores folder and started new geth sync from scratch without having any other data in our geth directory.

> Otherwise it probably will start to prune older data after a month or two to save on disk space, and you'll get the missing trie node error.

That's not quite how it works. Anyway, I'd recommend running the PR I linked, to see where the corruption resides, and also see if the database can be healed.

This issue has been automatically closed because there has been no response to our request for more information from the original author. With only the information that is currently in the issue, we don't have enough information to take action. Please reach out if you have more relevant information or answers to our questions so that we can investigate further.
@wbt where you able to resolve this issue?

@jayboy-mabushi I was able to solve these issues when I encountered them by adding `--gcmode "archive"` as a startup flag to geth + ensuring plenty of disk space, and suggested that to OP...but it's not clear to me what's going on for them.
